Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for possible plans).

I've run Chicago and New York. I haven't run Boston despite living ten minutes from the start line. (Still not fast enough to qualify. Still need to find 8 minutes.)
The majors are as much a carnival as they are a race. Never target one for a PB. Just getting to the start line is a huge undertaking. When you run one, it's best, I think to be sure to drink in the atmosphere and accept you're doing a part of something huge. They're so much fun, though. You meet so many people, everyone's having a great time.
If you're used to small local races, the sheer number of runners will blow your mind. If you weren't agoraphobic before, you will be after. Once you let yourself get carried in the human tide, though, it's actually a ton of fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69520193
I know that temptation, anon. It's a combination of boredom, competitive instinct, and desire to fast track improvement. These impulses can be addressed with Stoicism or Mindfulness Meditation, because these impulses are controllable once understood.

Imagine yourself on your next jog. What is your goal? Are you competing? Are you trying to gradually improve health? Do you seek entertainment? Once you define this goal (for me it is gradual improvement) then you'll recognize conflicting impulses and you'll have a chance to resist them (I resist the urge to accelerate). So you went slower than you wanted. So you were bored at times. So what? When you got home, you got the reward of improved health and had no dread of doing it again.

Put it in a very good index fund. bank deposit or some other really really safe, zero risk investment that provides some form of passive income. Then finish college and get a job. Use the money from the job to survive, use the passive income to learn how to invest properly in higher risk fields. DO NOT TOUCH YOUR 1.6 MILLION. Only when you've made at least 800k dollars from your riskier investments(aka half of that sum) on your own can you pull it out and meddle with it.
>inb4 why not start with the money I already have
Because they're a safety net and because you most likely are a noob when it comes to investing. You'll probably lose a whole bunch (if not all) if you start using them directly. It's much better to have the money as a safety net in case something happens (what if you get cancer?), earn some passive income from it, and use that extra money to experiment with investing at a small scale, rather than just go big from the get go, lose most of it and learn nothing. You know you're good enough with money and that you won't endanger your already existent 1.6 million when you manage to make at least half of that sum through your investments alone.

Also:
-learn to be thrift.
-steer clear from mind altering consumables (alcohol, shrooms, pills, other drugs)
-don't spend it on women. If you really must, you buy them a cheeseburger at most and that's it.
-margin and leverage are for people who already made millions, who know what they do and who want to improve profits, not for skrubs that want to get rich quick
-don't buy luxury goods (no, you don't need a fucking porsche, you can use a beat up 2nd hand that only costs 1k)
-don't tell a soul that you have money (another reason why you don't buy luxury goods is so you don't indirectly tell people that you have money)
-don't take investment advice that you didn't ask for (if you actually knew of a really good investment, would you go around telling people about it for free? No? Neither would they.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
“Last Thread Cancelled Due To Lack of Hustle” Edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For supple cetaceans who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

I'm left wing compared to the average poster here & my opinion is unpopular with both the left & the right. If you pass as a woman then you're a woman. It's not waterproof but it's the best option out of all of them. To be critical of the left: Self-identification isn't good enough. Someone can identify with something but if the world doesn't see them as that then every conversation with or about them is underpinned by the subtext, 'I'm going to call you by something which I don't really see you as but which you'd like to be seen as. I'm going to play a game of make-believe to avoid offending you'.
To criticize the right: Practicality underpins the definition of words. In a social context, a trans woman who passes IS a woman IMO because to refer to them otherwise is impractical. Like seeing a trans woman who passes in a restaurant, 'Look at that guy, over there, no over at that table, with the dress and the long brown hair, that dude' - You're just confusing people at that point where the purpose of language is to overcome confusion. Clarification: If we're in a doctor's office, or a sporting context, we go by sex terms because it doesn't matter if a trans woman passes or not when it comes to medical stuff or competitive sports.
My way of looking at this is never going to win out though because neither side would compromise on this. I'm basically saying pretty trans woman are women in a social context, which the right would say uuuhhh no, & the ugly manish ones aren't, which would make most lefties flip.

scramble/omelet some eggs in a skillet on low-med temp, add pepper/garlic seasoning as desired. Optionally cook some bacon/sausage/ham as well. Cook the eggs just enough to firm up, you don't want them to brown *at all*. Put in a plate

throw tortilla in skillet, apply mexican cheese mix liberally

once cheese starts to melt, add eggs and any meat. If you have salsa, dash some on there.

Check bottom of tortilla with a spatula. If its golden brown, fold it over and slap it in a plate. BAM! Egg quesadilla. If you balanced your seasoning right, and most importantly if you didn't overcook the eggs, then you will only taste the best qualities of them.

(5 eggs -> 2 quesadillas)

>wait til you see myceleum growth
>shake up the bag
>wait til bag covered in mycelleum, it is now "out" of new food to find, and therefore wants to spread it's genes via spore, aka mushroom fruiting body, but it will remain dormant until exposed to O2.
>crack open top of bag to give it O2, spray with water, keep it in as clean air as you can, keep it warm and moist but don't over-expose it to unfiltered air or touch it
>Receive more mushrooms in a month than you will ever want to use in the next 6 months if you have the balls to go into heroic dose territory

99% of humans on this planet won't know what the fuck they're looking at if they see this setup at any stage of the process. the amount of money needed to prosecute you for cultivation without actual attempt or intent to sell is not worth it for the state.

if you're serious about changing yourself this way then do your part and actually look into how insanely pragmatic fungi as a whole are, actually look into how it's helping people and what the future looks like in terms of fungi having applications for literally almost every facet of human life, industry, everything.

don't be the guy who goes into this just wanting to get high on drugs, do your part in being educated about it, you don't have to become a mushroom guru after you do 5 grams but you are almost directly hammering the nails into our species' coffin by doing something stupid and not taking this seriously.

I remembered a man overlooking a jungle and seeing a village being burned down by people off boats. I cried as he cried in my visions. I started remembering about this man and his dreams and aspirations. He wanted to fly. His left eye was impaired. I asked why he cried and I saw him being his younger self. He cried and I - without seeing the bodies - knew he had just buried his three daughters. I opened my eyes and in a hurry wrote down in capital letters:

"I HAVE HAD THREE DAUGHTERS"

The only thing I could remember was I was both glad to know about them but also shame to have forgotten them.

I then saw this man talking to villagers being an old man. Spreading his wisdom and pointing to the starry sky over this dense and moist jungle.

After the trip I started to realize I have been living a lie all along. I have been eating food not made for me, breathing air not meant for me and living a life without taking care of myself. If I could summarize the whole trip in one word it would be: CARE.

This was my first and I think last psychedelic experience and it was without a single of doubt the most important and significant experience in all my life.

>>69506296
>>69506401
If you genuinely don't want to kill yourself then you're going to be fine. Like the other anon said, in order to be a mentally ill fuckup on drugs you usually also need to be a mentally ill fuckup when you're sober, and if you're a schizo or serious mental illness runs in your family then you shouldn't do psychedelics (or other drugs) period. Stories about people leaping out windows thinking they can fly or peeling off their skin because they think they're an orange are just DARE bullshit. If you're a reasonable stable person taking a reasonable dose in a safe place (i.e don't do it in public, do it in your own home or a friend's place) you'll be fine. The biggest risk with psychedelics isn't physically harming yourself, it's having a bad trip on a really high dose and feeling complete mental despair for (what feels like) a really long time until you either manage to calm yourself down or the drug starts wearing off. I've had bad trips where I literally thought I was dead, or in a coma and being operated on and in those moments I was very conscious about my physical well-being and made sure not to damage my body, it's more of a mental thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69508988
They can give you a eureka moment that drastically change your attitude towards life, yourself and your habits, but for some people it's just a recreational drug that allows them to experience the world differently for a while, some people have bad trips and feel like shit for a while. They're not a magical pill you swallow to cure depression though. Clinical studies have shown very good results with addiction for smokers and anxiety about death for patients with cancer, they're also hopeful it'll be a good tool against depression but you have to keep in mind that's a guided trip session where you have professionals with you to help you make sense of all your thoughts while tripping. You can give it a try to see if you like it, just don't go in expecting it to fix all your problems.

Don't take more than you can handle (if you don't know your limit then start small and work your way up in increments), trip in a safe space (i.e your home, don't be a retard and take it in public) and have a laid back, accepting attitude towards things. Bad trips are just nasty thoughts in your head. The more you think about them and try to force them out of your head, the worse they get. It's like trying not to think about an elephant after somebody tells you not to think about an elephant. Accept that the thought exists in your head and it doesn't really mean anything unless you decide that it does. Once it's no longer 'taboo' it stops being an intrusive thought and you'll forget about it as soon as you get distracted by something else, which happens real fast on psychedelics.

>but ever since I had a bad trip (solipsistic crisis, realized my entire reality could be fake and I could be a lonely God)
Why does that make you unhappy? Is it the idea that it genuinely isn't real even if it feels real? What you live in and perceive is your reality, even if it isn't 'real'. It's real to you, this is the life you live. In this reality you have the freedom to pursue hobbies, friendship and love. You have senses that feel great to stimulate, whether that's eating good food, listening to music, viewing beautiful works of art or being caressed by someone you care about. I've had bad trips where I've come to the realization that I'm actually dead and everything I experience is just a cope by my brain which doesn't want to stop existing, and I've had bad trips where I got stuck in an infinite looping cycle. They were truly terrifying thoughts until I accepting that if this was the case then there's absolutely nothing I can do about it. Even then, if I was truly dead or had gone insane, I wasn' in any pain or discomfort. Quite the opposite, I was very comfortable in the safety of my own home, had I been hungry I could have eaten, had I wanted to I could have left that place if I felt it was like a prison - but I didn't. The more I thought about it as an opportunity to have a good time the less anxious I felt. Even if I am dead and you are a lonely schizo god we can still do the things we like doing. An eternity here is only a curse if you don't enjoy your stay.

Hello friends, as promised, this is my second week's update on my fasting.

Previous thread: >>69437986

Well, let's start of with the bad:

Turns out, the scale I had was broken and made me 6kg lighter than I actually was. At the start of the week, I was 173kg. I rectified this by buying a new scale and confirming its accuracy via my roommate's scale and my parent's scale.

I had 2 days where i "broke" my fast however, did not binge or go over my calories. On a re-feed day my brother brought me over some drinks I had (altogether around 400 cals) and today my mother insisted I eat some of her food (500 cals). Not bad, not great.

The good:

Down approx 3kg for the week to begin with, which was great. Currently at 170.

Increased the distance I can walk exponentially, so I should be burning more cals during my walking sessions.

The focus for next week:

I plan on correcting all my mistakes this week by only going to my parent's house when I am certain there is no food, or on a re-feed day.

Will focus on being as strict as possible on my fasting to speed up weightloss as well. Overall however I am happy with the outcome of this week.

Questions answered from some anons:

How did you get this big?

I broke both legs in a serious work accident which required 3 surgeries, months of rehab. On top of this I was living by myself, and fell into a deep depression because I was denied the only activity that gave me joy - lifting. It's a lonely world, the only thing I had was the gym. For 2 years I lived like this, finally after the physio said my legs where back to 100% i decided I will do everything I can to get back into shape.

Weightloss isn't exponential, ur there will go down over time so ur loss/week will decrease:

Yes, I am aware of this, the predicted weight takes into account this in the calculation.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69520752
the quickest way to vo2 max is to do high intensity training.

Peter doesn't do this type of training all the time, though. You should do your HIIT training maybe 1-2 times a week, and this is going all out for only 3-5 minutes.

The rest of the time, 3 times a week, he's doing zone 2 training which is about 70-80% of your max heart rate and you do it for at least 45 minutes, he does it for 2 hours. The goal is to build up mitochondria and lactate efficiency to improve performance at high intensities.

Cardiovascular health / vo2 max is associated with a 5.5x decrease in mortality risk vs muscular health at 3.5x. It doesn't take a whole lot of lifting to achieve the maximum longevity benefits from muscular health, it does take a lot to maximize cardiovascular health.

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.com:
Its an ok routine, but there are some things i would change. Deadlifting 2x a week seems unnecessary. I would suggest doing SSB squats instead of zercher squats and deadlifts. SSB squats will make you very strong, with lighter weights, so its easier to recover from. Also i would do the rowing chest supported, since your lower back already has a lot of volume. In general your program lacks volume for the upper back, as it recovers pretty fast.
Here is what i would change:
4 sets of SSB squats on squat day and 2 sets SSB good morning, instead of zercher squats and deadlifts. No ssb bar? Do fronts squats and normal good mornings.
You can also do some high bar pause squats or box squats on deadlift day, focusing on power. These will prime you for deadlifting.
Farmer walks on deadlift day, if possible. This will give you a very strong grip, and is imo better than shrugs.
Lat pulldown, 8x8 30 sec rest 50% 1rm on bench day or some kind of seal row supersetted with the bench press.
Hip thrust is ok, but i think 45 degree back extension is better, check out pete rubish back raises. You already have plenty of glute volume, so i would probably remove it, and do some more sets of other exercises.
Hamstring isolation. Glute ham raises, or leg curls
Some sort of lower trap/rear delt exercise, IYT raises will do this (very important)
Remove the shrugs, if you do the farmer walks.
Also, you do 3 sets for every exercise, feel free to play around with amount of sets. Instead of progressing weight, you can progress volume each week.
Also would add some 1 arm lat pulldowns on squat day. Upper back can be hit hard and frequently ik comparison to lower back.

t. 2/3/4/5 advanced lifter

I wouldnt add more btn presses, as you already have plenty of pressing, and more isnt always better. If you do, go for higher reps.

>>69520772
You could try doing reverse pyramid sets, or doing breakdowns (lowering weight each set, increasing rep range, so first set is 3-7, second is 8-14, third is 15-25). You could also just do straight sets, but with shorter rest (30 seconds) and do like 10 sets of the same number of repetitions, this will allow a higher amount of volume, and you will get more out of less weight, without a lot of tendon and cns stress. Also check out chuck sipes 1-10-1, vince gironda 8x8 and juarez valley pushups(good finisher, easy to progress, fun)
But all can work, play around and find something you like

>Most importantly for the IARC report, two major dietary intervention studies that should have contributed to the assessment of the claimed relationship of red meat and cancer were not considered. The first was a study of colon polyps, the precancerous growths that greatly increase the likelihood of developing colon cancer. Almost 1,900 subjects with a recent history of having a polyp removed were divided into a control group that ate their usual diet and a group following a diet characterized by significant decreases in total fat, red, and processed meat along with increases in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes (Schatzkin et al., 2000). Participants were followed for 3 years and at the end of that time, the recurrence of colon polyps was identical in both diet groups. It is possible that the precancerous stage may not have been the proper time for dietary intervention. The Women’s Health Initiative, therefore, studied a low-fat diet, achieved in large part by reducing red- and processed-meat consumption, among almost 49,000 women (Beresford et al., 2006); about 30,000 followed their normal diets and almost 20,000 were assigned to low-fat diets. After 9 years, the rate of colon cancer was almost identical in the low-fat and control-diet groups. These studies strongly suggest that the observational studies are not supported by dietary intervention studies at either the precancerous or malignant tumor stages of colon cancer.
https://doi.org/10.1093/af/vfy009

A swim cap is good but not needed if you're going to be doing it casually. Honestly man the best way to train for swimming is to swim for time but track how many laps you can do. Start with something like 4 sets for 3 minutes and slowly increase your time and sets to something more like 10 sets of 5 minutes. It'll take a while but once you can average more than 2.5 laps per minute in your 25m pool then increase the time or reps

I swim regularly, you need a swimming suit and goggles, the rest is irrelevant when you’re an amateur. If you plan on swimming in open water you might need some extra gear, but since you didn’t swim for a long period, just start in the pool. There’s no max to how many days you can swim in a week.

Because people are dumb
>use a ton of weight in a weak position they've never trained before
>rotator cuff explodes
>REEEEE HOW COULD THIS HAPPEN TO MEEE
Pretty much everyone should start with 20-30kg on this lift and work their way up slowly while also doing some rotator cuff work on the side. Overall it's probably better than OHP for hypertrophy as you get more side/rear delts, more upper back, and less systemic fatigue due to the lighter loads. You do get less upper chest though but OHP is pretty shit for upper chest anyway so it's not a big deal.

>>69518741
For me it was OHP>Squats=Bench>Deadlift (To be fair I never ended up deadlifting much because I only feel my glutes and lower back even with pristine technique so I'd rather do something else that doesn't fatigue me anywhere near as much)
>>69518754
While it is true that it's easy to turn OHP into a standing incline bench and that you can add quite a bit of weight to your press purely by optimizing the movement, I don't think you can add as much as compared to bench simply because you can't decrease the ROM on OHP by any appreciable amount. You can only increase the efficiency of your press and in the case of turning it into a standing incline bench you can improve your leverages slightly. On bench you can literally cut your ROM in half (or at least close to it) by going from a medium/narrow grip with a minimal arch to a wide grip with a huge arch. Someone benching 3 plates with a medium/narrow grip and with a minimal arch is not at all the same as someone benching 3 plates with a wide grip and a huge arch; the former is going to have a much larger upper body in pretty much all cases. Meanwhile two individuals OHPing similar numbers will be fairly comparable due to the above factors unless they have a huge discrepancy in limb lengths.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69518798
Yeah in that sense you are right. I always go for full maximum ROM, but with the most "efficient" bar path/mechanics. I squat high bar because it feels the most natural and secure to me, but have issues with knee caving and folding over anytime it gets too heavy.

I exclusively do close grip benching (shoulder width) now, slight arch to set my shoulders/back and enable some leg drive but with a really great ROM. Going wider allows more weight but absolutely wrecks recovery for me on concurrent sessions in the same week, the connective tissue around my upper pecs towards the delts need 4+ days of recovery before I can bench heavy wide again without getting pain in that area. None of that when I go close grip, I also psychologically feel safer about my shoulders despite never having any big issues when tucking vs flaring.

I don't even know how this is possible, the moment I unlock my knees I can instantly tell; this isn't like rounding the back on deadlifts where people with shit proprioception may not notice that it's happening, your knees unlocking is extremely obvious and noticable (plus to use leg drive you have to move down a bit, which is also extremely obvious since during a strict press your body shouldn't descend at all)
>>69519693
More that the way a lot of people perform it turns it into an ego lift. A medium/close grip bench press with a minimal arch is a great exercise; a super wide grip bench with an enormous arch is an abomination that only serves to show how much weight you can move through a 2" range of motion. If everybody performed the former lift, it would be a better test of upper-body strength than OHP since you can move more weight through a significant ROM while involving more muscle mass. Of course, in the real world people when optimizing their bench will steadily widen their grip and increase their arch to put more pounds on the bar, which means you end up having two dudes benching the same weight with similar proportions but one is significantly less muscular because he's doing the lift through a tiny range of motion. The same thing doesn't happen (or at least, is very rare) with OHP.

I’m one of the few percentages of people who couldn’t lose weight due to “certain rare conditions”

I'm a socially anxious guy working on going alcohol free, so I'll share a story that might be of a bit of relevance.

I was a groomsman at a wedding for one of my friends and I drank very little out of choice and respect for the wedding couple.
I have a knack to fly off the handle with booze sometimes since I don't drink much, so I just sipped light beer and stayed in a barely buzzed state all night.
I pushed myself to do things that were uncomfortable without being in a drunken stupor, including some dancing; and I think I got a lot of respect from women for being the most sober guy there but still doing things like dancing, socializing, and what not; even though I wasn't as exciting as the extremely drunk people.
My takeaway was: you get the halo effect if you can be sober and do things that most people can only do drunk.
I have a lot of respect for people that can go to events and not drink, and want to become one of those people myself.
Work on it, anon. Start small (introducing yourself and saying hi), and work your way up (full blown conversations, etc.).

Hmm. Don't rush to the harder levels before you've gotten the practice in on the easier ones first.
As in start with just saying hi, or just making eye contact and smiling, to people in passing.
From there move on to asking closed ended questions off of the hello - "nice weather today, isn't it?"
Level up to asking closed ended questions - "do you know where I can find a good restaurant/coffeeshop around here?"
Eventually you put all the pieces from the easier stuff together, and asking a girl out isn't a life or death situation.
